body: Are you seeing this on head as well?

Version 1.54.3 right now is the latest version that is available on [conan.io](https://conan.io/center/recipes/grpc). Unfortunately it is not feasible for me to try this out with head unless there is a conan recipe. Looking at the [code](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/9cf228b8a4f126e84eb62fc271d1b683703a61e5/src/core/lib/promise/pipe.h#L65), the root cause for this bug is still there on head (the member `cancelled_` is not initialized).

I was able to reproduce this error in 1.60.1:
```
src/core/lib/promise/pipe.h:74:3: runtime error: load of value 73, which is not a valid value for type 'bool'
```

I am building with the `Debug` configuration.

I can also verify this on 1.60.0:
`src/core/lib/promise/pipe.h:74:3: runtime error: load of value 216, which is not a valid value for type 'bool'`

issue.title: Fix reading of uninitialized bool (cancelled_) upon moving NextResult.

labels.name: release notes: no
labels.description: Indicates if PR should not be in release notes

repository.name: grpc
repository.description: C++ based gRPC (C++, Python, Ruby, Objective-C, PHP, C#)

issue.body:
Hello,
This should hopefully fix #35381, or at least eliminate one possible cause.

This is a classical uninitialized variable:
- Not all constructors initialize `cancelled_`.
- We rely on the compiler-provided move operations, which unconditionally copy all non-static data members.
- As a result, a move operation reads from an uninitialized `cancelled_`.

It is probably innocuous in that context, but it is still undefined behavior.
I see two possible ways to fix it:
1. Always initizalize `cancelled_`.
2. Don't rely on the compiler-provided move operations, and implement it manually so it skips the `cancelled_` field when not relevant.

This fix takes path 1, filling in semantically correct values (even though they should not be used). Happy to change it if needed.
